elements.name: House Welcome Card: Pre-Move-In Community Activation
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests move into shared houses with zero knowledge of who they will live with -- the anti-magic moment that PadSplit normalizes.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform introduces you to your housemate before you arrive. This card transforms the anxious gap between acceptance and move-in into a warm social preview that builds trust before the first handshake.
elements.description: A card shown to guests after their proposal is accepted, displaying their co-tenant's anonymized profile: work schedule pattern, lifestyle preferences (quiet/social, early bird/night owl), a short personal intro, and their Passport score if they have one. Includes a 'Send a hello' action that initiates a brief introductory message. The card is designed to feel like meeting a neighbor, not evaluating a roommate.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, max-width 420px. Top section: co-tenant avatar placeholder (abstract pattern, not a face) with schedule overlap visualization. Middle section: preference chips and personal intro. Bottom section: CTA button.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for the heading and schedule overlap bars to signal brand trust. Secondary purple for preference chips and the CTA. Off-white background for the intro section to create visual separation. Success color (#4B47CE) for the Passport score indicator.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card appears with a subtle slide-up animation (0.3s ease-out) after proposal acceptance. Co-tenant profile loads with a gentle fade-in.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates with shadow transition (--shadow-sm to --shadow-md). CTA button shifts from secondary-purple to accent-purple.
interaction_spec.click: 'Send a hello' opens an inline message composer with a pre-filled friendly template the guest can customize.
interaction_spec.animation: Schedule overlap bars animate in from left to right (0.4s ease-out, 0.1s stagger). Preference chips fade in sequentially (0.2s each).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile with reduced padding (16px). Schedule visualization stacks vertically below 400px.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Here's a preview of who shares the space at 142 W 72nd St. You'll overlap on weekday evenings and weekends.
micro_copy: Schedule preferences: Night owl, Quiet mornings, Social weekends
do: Use warm, conversational tone -- this is a social introduction, not a data report
Frame schedule overlaps as useful information, not compatibility scores
Show the Passport score as a trust signal, not a rating
dont: Don't use 'compatibility match' language -- this isn't a dating app
Don't show a numerical compatibility percentage
Don't display the co-tenant's real name or photo without their explicit opt-in

before_after.before: PadSplit: Member gets approved, receives a move-in date, key code, and house rules PDF. Walks into a house of strangers on day one. No profiles, no introductions, no social context. The first time they learn anything about their housemates is when they hear them through the walls.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After acceptance, guest sees a House Welcome Card with their co-tenant's schedule overlap, lifestyle preferences, personal intro, and Passport score. They can send a hello message before move-in day. By the time they walk through the door, they already know a name, a rhythm, and a shared context.

elements.name: Engagement Ladder Progress Strip
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit's member experience is a flatline -- month 1 and month 12 are identical. There is no progressive value, no engagement ladder, no reason to deepen engagement over time.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform rewards tenure with progressively valuable capabilities. This strip transforms the Stays Manager from a billing portal into an engagement engine that reveals new value at each milestone.
elements.description: A horizontal progress strip integrated into the Stays Manager dashboard, showing the guest's current engagement tier and what unlocks next. Three tiers visible: 'Getting Settled' (weeks 1-4), 'Established' (weeks 5-8, unlocks coordination tools and co-tenant feedback), and 'House Anchor' (weeks 9+, unlocks profile influence, priority dates, and deposit credit). Current tier is highlighted with a progress indicator. The next unlock is teased with a subtle preview.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width horizontal strip, height 72px. Three tier segments with connecting progress bar. Fits within the Stays Manager header area.
visual_spec.background: Linear gradient from rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.03) to rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.06)
visual_spec.color_usage: Completed tier segments use secondary-purple fill. Current tier uses a pulsing accent-purple dot. Future tiers use muted gray. The progress bar uses a gradient from secondary-purple to accent-purple.

interaction_spec.default_state: Strip shows three tier labels with icons, a progress bar at the current position, and a subtle 'Next: [unlock name]' preview for the upcoming tier.
interaction_spec.hover: Hovering over any tier reveals a tooltip with the full list of capabilities at that tier.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking the current tier opens a detail panel showing earned capabilities, progress toward the next tier, and what actions accelerate progression.
interaction_spec.animation: Progress bar fills with a smooth animation (0.6s ease-out) on page load. Current tier dot pulses gently (2s infinite). Next-tier teaser fades in after progress bar completes.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, tiers stack vertically as a compact timeline. Progress indicator shifts to a vertical bar on the left.

do: Use milestone language, not gamification language -- 'Established' not 'Level 2'
Show concrete capabilities that unlock, not abstract points
Frame progression as natural tenure recognition, not a grind
dont: Don't use XP, points, or score language -- this isn't a game
Don't show a percentage that makes early weeks feel demotivating ('15% complete')
Don't gate essential features behind tiers -- date changes and basic tools are always available

elements.name: Shared Housing Passport Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit members build zero portable reputation -- months of on-time payments and good behavior generate no transferable value. Every new lease starts from scratch.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform creates a cumulative, portable trust profile. This card is the guest's professional identity in the shared-housing world -- a living document that compounds trust over time and creates real switching costs.
elements.description: A profile card that displays the guest's Shared Housing Passport: a cumulative trust score built from weekly micro-reviews, payment reliability, co-tenant feedback, and tenure across leases. Shows the trust score as a prominent number, a temporal graph of micro-review trends, key metrics (consecutive positive weeks, total leases, payment reliability), and verified trust signals. This card appears on the guest's profile (visible to prospective hosts), on the House Welcome Card (visible to prospective co-tenants), and in search results (as a trust badge).

visual_spec.layout: Card with header badge area, score display, metric strip, and trust timeline. Max-width 380px.
visual_spec.background: #ffffff with a subtle top gradient banner (primary-purple to secondary-purple)
visual_spec.color_usage: Purple gradient header conveys authority and trust. Score uses primary-purple for gravitas. Metric icons use success-color (#4B47CE). Timeline uses secondary-purple for positive weeks, muted gray for neutral.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card displays the score, top metrics, and a sparkline of recent weeks. Compact view suitable for embedding in other contexts.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates. Sparkline expands to show individual week markers with scores.
interaction_spec.click: Expands to full Passport view with detailed timeline, lease history, and endorsements.
interaction_spec.animation: Score counts up from 0 to current value on first view (0.8s ease-out). Sparkline draws left-to-right (0.6s ease-out). Metrics fade in with stagger (0.15s each).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Score and sparkline stack vertically. Metrics become a scrollable horizontal strip.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Trust built over time, verified by the people you've lived with.
do: Frame as a professional credential, not a report card
Emphasize the narrative ('26 consecutive positive weeks') over the number (4.8)
Show the trajectory -- is the score improving, stable, or declining?
dont: Don't make it look like a credit score dashboard
Don't show raw review text on the compact card -- save detail for the expanded view
Don't display a score below 3.0 publicly -- below that threshold, show 'Building your Passport' instead

elements.name: House Anchor Badge and Influence Panel
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit does not identify, tool, or reward the members who do disproportionate community-building labor -- the 'hard side' at the house level that Chen identifies as critical to network stability.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform formally recognizes the member who makes the house work. This badge and panel transform invisible community labor into visible, rewarded status.
elements.description: A badge that appears on the Stays Manager and guest profile once House Anchor status is earned, along with an influence panel that gives Anchors specific tools: preview profiles of incoming co-tenants (Passport data), write the welcome note new co-tenants see during pre-move-in onboarding, and submit a house community referral (invite a specific person to their specific house). The badge includes concrete benefits: priority date selection and a deposit credit toward their next lease.

visual_spec.layout: Badge: inline element 28px tall, pill shape. Panel: dropdown panel max-width 360px, attached to the badge location.
visual_spec.background: Badge: gradient from #31135D to secondary-purple. Panel: white with subtle purple-tinted top border.
visual_spec.border: Panel: 1px solid #e5e7eb, 3px top border in secondary-purple
visual_spec.color_usage: Badge uses the primary-to-secondary purple gradient to convey earned authority. Star icon in white. Panel actions use secondary-purple for CTAs. Benefit indicators use success-color (#4B47CE).

interaction_spec.default_state: Badge appears inline in the Stays Manager header and on the guest profile. Subtle shimmer animation on first earn.
interaction_spec.hover: Badge shows a tooltip: 'House Anchor -- tap to see your influence tools.'
interaction_spec.click: Opens the influence panel with three action areas: Preview incoming co-tenants, Write welcome note, Refer a friend to this house.
interaction_spec.animation: Badge entrance: scale from 0.8 to 1.0 with overshoot (0.4s spring easing). Panel: slides down from badge position (0.2s ease-out).
interaction_spec.responsive: Badge remains inline at all sizes. Panel becomes a full-width bottom sheet on mobile.

copy_spec.secondary_text: You've earned influence at 142 W 72nd St.
micro_copy: Invite a friend to this house
do: Frame as earned recognition, not a job assignment
Emphasize 'influence' not 'control' -- Anchors shape, they don't gatekeep
Show concrete benefits alongside tools
dont: Don't use 'manager' or 'admin' language -- Anchors are peers, not bosses
Don't imply Anchors can block co-tenants -- they preview and advise, not veto
Don't make the badge look corporate -- it should feel like a community honor

before_after.before: PadSplit: Every member is identical -- same rules, same interface, same relationship with the platform. The member who coordinates trash schedules, mediates conflicts, and welcomes newcomers gets the same treatment as someone who just pays rent and stays in their room. The hard side is invisible and unrewarded.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After 9+ weeks of positive engagement, guests earn the House Anchor badge with concrete tools (preview incoming co-tenants, write welcome notes, refer friends) and real benefits (priority dates, deposit credit). The hard side is identified, empowered, and retained.

elements.name: House Personality Search Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit search hides the most important variable in shared housing -- the people -- forcing guests to make life decisions based on room specs and price alone.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform lets you search by house personality. This card makes the social composition of a house visible during search, transforming room-shopping into community-finding.
elements.description: A search result card that leads with the house personality rather than room specs. Shows a brief auto-generated house summary based on co-tenant profiles and micro-review themes, schedule compatibility indicator (low/medium/high overlap with the searching guest's stated schedule), lifestyle chips (quiet, social, early bird, etc.), and the house's aggregate Passport score. Price and amenities are secondary, visible but not dominant. The card answers 'who lives here?' before 'what does the room cost?'

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal card, full search-result width. Left section: house photo (40% width). Right section: personality summary, compatibility indicator, chips, then price/details row at bottom.

spacing.padding: 0 (image flush left) with 16px padding on text section

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for personality headline. Compatibility indicator uses a color scale: high overlap = success-color (#4B47CE), medium = accent-purple, low = text-gray. Lifestyle chips use the same style as the House Welcome Card for consistency.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card displays house photo, personality headline, compatibility badge, 2-3 lifestyle chips, price, and a subtle co-tenant count indicator.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates with shadow transition. Compatibility indicator expands to show schedule overlap detail.
interaction_spec.click: Navigates to full listing page with House Welcome Card content (co-tenant profiles, schedule visualization, full personality description).
interaction_spec.animation: Cards stagger-fade in during search results load (0.15s delay between each). Compatibility badge pulses gently on high-compatibility results.
interaction_spec.responsive: Stacks vertically on mobile: photo on top (full width), personality content below.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Night-shift healthcare and remote developers. Shared kitchen active on weekends. Minimal weekday overlap.
do: Lead with personality, not price -- the personality is what differentiates from PadSplit
Use natural language for house descriptions, not tag-soup
Show compatibility as a gentle signal, not a hard match score
dont: Don't show co-tenant names or identifiable photos in search results
Don't make low-compatibility results look like warnings -- some guests prefer minimal overlap
Don't hide price entirely -- it's still a decision factor, just not the headline

elements.name: House Continuity Welcome Note
elements.problem_it_solves: Every co-tenant transition in PadSplit recreates the Cold Start Problem at the house level -- no institutional knowledge transfer, no welcome ritual, no preserved social context across turnovers.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform preserves house culture across turnovers. This welcome note, written by the House Anchor, bridges the social gap between departing and arriving co-tenants, preventing the perpetual cold start.
elements.description: A section within the pre-move-in House Welcome flow that displays a personal welcome note written by the current House Anchor (or host). The note includes practical tips specific to this house (where to find extra towels, the best coffee spot nearby, parking quirks), the house's unwritten norms (quiet after 10pm, kitchen cleanup same-day, packages go on the side table), and a personal greeting. This note is updated by the Anchor each time a new co-tenant is arriving and persists across turnovers, becoming a living house manual written by the people who actually live there.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width section within the pre-move-in flow. Card-style container with an author attribution header and a freeform content area.
visual_spec.background: Warm off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) with a left border accent in secondary-purple
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb, with 3px left border in secondary-purple
visual_spec.color_usage: Left border accent in secondary-purple signals this is a personal message, not system-generated. Author attribution uses primary-purple for the name. Tip bullets use a subtle purple dot. The warm background differentiates this from data-driven sections.

interaction_spec.default_state: Note displays with the author's attribution and Anchor badge, followed by the welcome message and house tips. Collapsed if longer than 5 lines, with 'Read more' expand.
interaction_spec.hover: No hover state -- this is a reading section, not an interactive element.
interaction_spec.click: 'Read more' expands the full note. 'Say thanks' button sends a pre-filled appreciation message to the Anchor.
interaction_spec.animation: Fades in with a handwritten-style motion (slight rotation settle, 0.3s ease-out) to feel personal, not generated.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on all sizes. Left border becomes a top border on mobile for thumb-friendly layout.

copy_spec.primary_text: A note from your House Anchor
copy_spec.secondary_text: Sarah has been at 142 W 72nd St for 8 months and knows the ins and outs.
do: Encourage Anchors to write naturally -- this should feel like a text from a friend, not a hotel concierge manual
Include practical specifics that only a resident would know
Show when the note was last updated to signal freshness
dont: Don't auto-generate the note content -- it must be authentically written by the Anchor
Don't require a minimum length -- a three-sentence warm welcome is better than a forced essay
Don't display the Anchor's full name without consent -- first name and initial is sufficient

before_after.before: PadSplit: New member receives a house rules PDF and a key code. No personal welcome, no resident tips, no sense of who lives there or how the house works. Every move-in recreates the Cold Start Problem because no social context survives turnovers.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Before move-in, the guest reads a personal welcome note from the House Anchor: practical tips only a resident would know, the house's unwritten norms, and a warm greeting. The house's social capital persists across turnovers because the Anchor maintains it.

elements.name: Community Referral Invitation Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit referrals are generic platform marketing -- a member shares a link for a cash bonus, and the referred person ends up in a random house. Referrals generate volume without strengthening any house's network.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform lets you invite a specific friend to your specific house. This transforms referrals from a marketing mechanism to a community-building mechanism, generating the Acquisition Effect that Chen identifies as essential for Escape Velocity.
elements.description: A card available to House Anchors (and after a tenure threshold, all guests) that lets them invite a specific person to their specific house. The card shows what the invited person will see: the house personality, the inviter's welcome note, and a personal message. The referral is tied to a specific house, not the generic platform, meaning the invited person arrives with a pre-existing social connection. Both parties receive a community bonus (deposit credit, not just cash) that incentivizes house-level referrals over platform-level ones.

visual_spec.layout: Card with a preview section (showing what the invitee will see) and a simple invite form. Max-width 440px.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for the heading. The preview section uses off-white background to simulate what the invitee will see. The bonus indicator uses success-color. The invite button uses the standard secondary-purple CTA style.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows the invite headline, a preview of the house personality card the invitee will see, and fields for the friend's name and message.
interaction_spec.hover: Preview section elevates slightly. Send button shows hover state.
interaction_spec.click: Send button generates a unique invite link tied to this specific house. Confirmation shows: 'Invitation sent! If [Name] joins 142 W 72nd St, you both earn a $50 deposit credit.'
interaction_spec.animation: Preview section pulses gently to draw attention. Success state shows confetti-style purple particles (subtle, 1.5s).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Preview section becomes scrollable if it extends below fold.

copy_spec.primary_text: Invite a friend to your house
copy_spec.secondary_text: Know someone who'd be a great fit at 142 W 72nd St? Invite them directly -- they'll see your personal recommendation.
micro_copy: Both of you earn a $50 deposit credit
Your friend will see the house personality and your welcome note
This isn't a generic referral -- it's a community invitation
do: Frame as a community invitation, not a marketing referral
Emphasize the personal connection: 'your friend' not 'a new user'
Show the mutual benefit clearly
dont: Don't use 'refer a friend' language -- use 'invite' instead
Don't make the cash incentive the headline -- the community connection is the headline
Don't allow invitations to generic platform signup -- the invitation must be to a specific house

before_after.before: PadSplit: Member shares a generic referral link for a $50 cash bonus. The referred person enters PadSplit's generic application flow and may end up in a completely different city. Referrer and referred have no connection within the platform. The referral generates volume without strengthening any house network.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Guest invites a specific friend to their specific house. The friend sees the house personality, the inviter's welcome note, and applies to that house directly.
